linkTarget.anchoringText: The Permian Basin (Figure 1) continues to be the most prolific oil producing region in the nation (EIA, 2017). Continued advancements in hydraulic fracturing techniques, horizontal drilling and advanced diagnostic tools have greatly increased development in unconventional reservoirs. The previous work, SPE 175535 (Parker et al., 2015) discussed traditional fracture optimization methods and design variables including fluid and proppant selection and fracture conductivity enhancement to promote well performance improvements and introduced stage size, cluster spacing and perforation efficiency design methods.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: The Permian Basin showing the Delaware Basin, the Central Platform and the Midland Basin and formations within each sub-basin (courtesy Shale Experts).

formatted-caption.caption-text: The Permian Basin showing the Delaware Basin, the Central Platform and the Midland Basin and formations within each sub-basin (courtesy Shale Experts).

linkTarget.anchoringText: The engineered design methodology discussed resulted in significant improvements to well performance, allowed for a systematic method to validate parameters and provided the basis-of-design for benchmarking well performance. Key parameters, engineering tools and methods are necessary to evaluate completion efficiency and hydrocarbon productivity of the reservoir in order to design optimal fracture treatments in unconventional reservoirs (Meyer et al., 2013). Figure 2 shows the locations of Wells A-F and offset technology Well G in Reeves County, Texas, used in this study.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Location for field trial Wells A-F in this study and offset technology Well G.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Location for field trial Wells A-F in this study and offset technology Well G.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Core data from Well G (vertical) was used to calibrate and enhance the confidence of the log-derived reservoir characteristic used for natural fracture spacing estimates, fluid leakoff calculations, mechanical rock properties and in-situ stress calculations necessary for DFN fracture modeling. Minor adjustments were required to calibrate with DFIT results conducted in the toe of Well B. The core points and the calibrated logs used in the fracture modeling are presented in Figure 3 showing favorable agreement with the inputs.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Core calibrated, log-derived porosity, permeability and mechanical rock properties for Well G.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Core calibrated, log-derived porosity, permeability and mechanical rock properties for Well G.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Applied Post-Job Analytics (APJA) is a post-job engineering based analysis and methodology designed to determine the number of contributing transverse fractures (clusters) in horizontal wellbores, fracturing pressure components and the fracture characteristic half-lengths per stage. Table 3 presents the APJA cluster performance results for Wells A-F. Although the industry usually communicates in terms of cluster efficiency, a more useful metric is the number of fractures per 1,000 ft and the equivalent cluster spacing between open clusters. All three metrics should be considered. Figures 4 and 5 show the APJA cluster analysis results for Well D.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Analysis results showing designed number of clusters per stage (5) compared to actual number of clusters open per stage for Well D.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Analysis results showing designed number of clusters per stage (5) compared to actual number of clusters open per stage for Well D.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Applied Post-Job Analytics (APJA) is a post-job engineering based analysis and methodology designed to determine the number of contributing transverse fractures (clusters) in horizontal wellbores, fracturing pressure components and the fracture characteristic half-lengths per stage. Table 3 presents the APJA cluster performance results for Wells A-F. Although the industry usually communicates in terms of cluster efficiency, a more useful metric is the number of fractures per 1,000 ft and the equivalent cluster spacing between open clusters. All three metrics should be considered. Figures 4 and 5 show the APJA cluster analysis results for Well D.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Completion efficiency type curve shows Well D has a cluster efficiency of 65%. A total of 80 clusters are open (124 shot) and results indicate 16 contributing transverse fractures per 1000’ of lateral at an equailvant spacing of 63 ft.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Completion efficiency type curve shows Well D has a cluster efficiency of 65%. A total of 80 clusters are open (124 shot) and results indicate 16 contributing transverse fractures per 1000’ of lateral at an equailvant spacing of 63 ft.

linkTarget.anchoringText: However, there is a marked difference in the complex back stress. This is because the hybrid completions utilized crosslink fluid and larger grain proppant (20/40 or greater) compared to the current smaller grain proppant (40/70 or less) and slickwater type design. The secondary and tertiary fracture apertures were created with a significantly more viscous fluid than slickwater and more pressure was generated. Figure 6 shows the percentage of pressure components seen in Well D by category of pressure.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Average Storage+MFC, Complex Back Stress and Width-Opening Net comprise 64%, 15% and 21% respectively, of the total Apparent Net Pressure of 1,273 psi for Well D.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Average Storage+MFC, Complex Back Stress and Width-Opening Net comprise 64%, 15% and 21% respectively, of the total Apparent Net Pressure of 1,273 psi for Well D.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The analysis of the data for cluster contributions is very subjective, as such, the interpretations were primarily used as a check between APJA and RTA for contributing clusters. The results seen in Figures 7 and 8 may suggest a cluster efficiency of 69% which compares reasonably well to the APJA and RTA results for Well B presented in Table 3 (75%). The tracer material and stage pumped is varied by color and width of color indicates stage contribution during the sampling period.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Frac fluid tracer (CFT) flowback performance for Well B.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Frac fluid tracer (CFT) flowback performance for Well B.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The analysis of the data for cluster contributions is very subjective, as such, the interpretations were primarily used as a check between APJA and RTA for contributing clusters. The results seen in Figures 7 and 8 may suggest a cluster efficiency of 69% which compares reasonably well to the APJA and RTA results for Well B presented in Table 3 (75%). The tracer material and stage pumped is varied by color and width of color indicates stage contribution during the sampling period.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Hydrocarbon fluid tracer (OFT) flowback performance for Well B.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Hydrocarbon fluid tracer (OFT) flowback performance for Well B.

linkTarget.anchoringText: DFN pressure matching with updated and calibrated inputs was performed for Well D, Stage 9 which was completed with 25 stages, 5 clusters per stage and 200 ft stage spacing. The surface and bottomhole pressure match is shown in Figure 9.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Surface and bottom hole pressure match for Well D, rate, and proppant concentration. Measured pressure is green and model pressure is blue.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Surface and bottom hole pressure match for Well D, rate, and proppant concentration. Measured pressure is green and model pressure is blue.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Total created fracture height is approximately 525 ft on average. This is supported by the nearby microseismic data for Well A (Figure 10) but in the previous work the upper microseismic events were ignored because it did not match the initial assumptions and the fracture height was limited to 225 ft based on the data cloud. Additionally, the job design for Well D was double that of Well A, so additional fracture height would be expected.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Microseismic fracture mapping of Well A showing average total fracture height of 525 ft with fractures contained between the Wolfcamp A and growing up through the Lower 3rd Bone Spring.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Microseismic fracture mapping of Well A showing average total fracture height of 525 ft with fractures contained between the Wolfcamp A and growing up through the Lower 3rd Bone Spring.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Several authors (Lehman et. al., (2016), Friedrich and Milliken (2013), Zakhour et al., (2015), and Rodriguez (2017)) have shown similar (or greater) fracture heights in the Delaware and Midland basins and further work by the authors support 525 ft of fracture height. The microseismic data from offset Well A (Figure 11) which was interpreted to have 700 ft of total fracture length (fracture half-length of 325 ft). Again, the fracture length for Well D would be expected to be greater as the job volumes were doubled.

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Microseismic fracture mapping of Well A showing average total length of approximately 700 ft.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Microseismic fracture mapping of Well A showing average total length of approximately 700 ft.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The microseismic data from offset Well A (Figure 11) which was interpreted to have 700 ft of total fracture length (fracture half-length of 325 ft). Again, the fracture length for Well D would be expected to be greater as the job volumes were doubled. The DFN pressure match resulted in an average created and propped fracture half-length of 632 ft and 364 ft respectively as shown in Figure 12 and aligns with microseismic data.

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Stress and concentration/area at closure showing propped fracture half-length out to 364 ft. Upper Wolfcamp A shown in maroon, Lower Wolfcamp A shown in green, Lower 3rd Bone Spring in gold and Upper 3rd Bone Spring in grey.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Stress and concentration/area at closure showing propped fracture half-length out to 364 ft. Upper Wolfcamp A shown in maroon, Lower Wolfcamp A shown in green, Lower 3rd Bone Spring in gold and Upper 3rd Bone Spring in grey.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Solutions were determined for the apparent net pressure, true width-opening pressure, mid-field fracture complexity, complex back stress, created length, maximum proppant length (plug displacement), likely proppant length (settled bank) and settled bank height. Likely proppant length can be considered propped length when compared to the DFN model and effective length when compared to the PHM and RTA. Results for the APJA solutions are presented in Table 4 and Figure 13.

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: Plan view of created length, maximum proppant length (plug displacement) and likely proppant length (settled bank) for shown in Table 4 for Well D.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Plan view of created length, maximum proppant length (plug displacement) and likely proppant length (settled bank) for shown in Table 4 for Well D.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The production history match with the BHFP ranging from 6,800-4,400 psi is shown in Figure 14. The bubble point pressure of 3,800 psi was determined from PVT analysis. Results are presented in Table 5. The propped half-length for Well D is 350 ft which was used to calibrate the effective fracture half-length in the DFN fracture model shown in Figure 12. The designs with increased lbm/ft loading resulted in increased propped fracture half-lengths with the exception of Well A, which utilized 1,200 lbm/ft and shows a propped half-length 193 ft., compared to Well B that had 1,500 lbm/ ft with a propped half-length of 195 ft, respectively.

image-wrap.label: Figure 14
image-wrap.caption: Production history match with BHFP for Well D.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Production history match with BHFP for Well D.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The authors find the methodology very useful to identify and bound solutions such as the number of contributing clusters, effective fracture half-length, propped fracture height and permeability. From this analysis (Figure 15), the permeability, number of clusters, propped fracture height and propped half-length is most likely 386 nD, 78, 130 ft and 358 ft respectively. The permeability ties well to core values, the cluster efficiency is similar to APJA and OFT/CFT analysis and the fracture geometry parameters correlate well to the DFN modeling, PHA, and APJA.

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: Most likely probabilistic analysis from RTA.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Most likely probabilistic analysis from RTA.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 16 shows the actual 120 day production results for the culmination of engineering efforts and technology integration to improve fracture stimulation design, cluster efficiency and job execution. Results are normalized to 7,500 ft lateral length. The 5,000 lbm/ft and 4,000 lbm/ft are single wells and the remaining curves are production averages for the wells completed with that design.

image-wrap.label: Figure 16
image-wrap.caption: Cumulative oil production results for various proppant loading designs normalized to 7,500 ft lateral.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Cumulative oil production results for various proppant loading designs normalized to 7,500 ft lateral.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 17 shows the forecast of cumulative 10 year EUR performance with different job designs for Wells A-F. It is an important part of the completion optimization process to understand the resulting trends in production performance, with the changes in fracture characteristics, based on the job design and number of contributing clusters. The results indicate that larger job designs result in increased production as supported by field data. This is also seen in Figure 18, the Average Productivity Ratio, that larger jobs increase productivity.

image-wrap.label: Figure 17
image-wrap.caption: Production forecast for various proppant loading designs normalized to 7,500 ft lateral.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Production forecast for various proppant loading designs normalized to 7,500 ft lateral.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 17 shows the forecast of cumulative 10 year EUR performance with different job designs for Wells A-F. It is an important part of the completion optimization process to understand the resulting trends in production performance, with the changes in fracture characteristics, based on the job design and number of contributing clusters. The results indicate that larger job designs result in increased production as supported by field data. This is also seen in Figure 18, the Average Productivity Ratio, that larger jobs increase productivity.

image-wrap.label: Figure 18
image-wrap.caption: Average productivity ratio for various proppant loading designs normalized to 7,500 ft lateral.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Average productivity ratio for various proppant loading designs normalized to 7,500 ft lateral.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The improved well performance was worth the additional completion cost required for increased proppant mass and fluid volumes in the enhanced designs. Table 8 shows a summary of percent production uplift and the increased cost percentage to obtain the production above the 1,200 lbm/ft design. Figures 19-22 presents the Discounted Return on Investment (DROI) for each job design by transverse fractures, propped fracture half-length, over a 10 year period and relative to each other, respectively.

image-wrap.label: Figure 19
image-wrap.caption: DROI for the number of contributing transverse fractures for 1 yr, 5 yr and 10 yrs.

formatted-caption.caption-text: DROI for the number of contributing transverse fractures for 1 yr, 5 yr and 10 yrs.
